body: What model are you trying to convert? Can you explain the use case where you need boolean as input?

@prabhat00155 I'm not sure exactly how to answer that, but here I try.

It's a model I'm building myself, it takes samples from a dataframe and some of the features are boolean values (yes or no values) and it predicts a number. You can think of it as for example a way to predict, say, prices from a set of product characteristics

It is possible I am missing something and I could convert the boolean input into another type, but my ML knowledge is not good enough to be sure what to use instead :)

For the record, my model is a pipeline with:
- a `ColumnTransformer` to encode some of the feature
  - I was planning to not encode it
- a XGBoost regressor (which supports boolean input)
I see, for the time being, you may cast those boolean features to int using dataframe.astype(int). Meanwhile, I'll see what needs to be done in order to support bool.

@prabhat00155 ok thanks. Actually, I had to cast them to float because I got the following error:
```
  File "/home/victor/.cache/pypoetry/virtualenvs/venv-51Be8MFl-py3.7/lib/python3.7/site-packages/skl2onnx/shape_calculators/concat.py", line 41, in calculate_sklearn_concat
    + inps)
RuntimeError: Columns must have the same type. C++ backends do not support mixed types. Inputs:
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable1', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable2', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable3', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable4', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='feat1', onnx_name='has_treatment', type=Int64TensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='feat2', onnx_name='is_beartex', type=Int64TensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='feat3', onnx_name='is_norax', type=Int64TensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable5', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable6', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable7', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable8', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable9', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable10', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable11', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable12', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
Variable(raw_name='variable', onnx_name='variable13', type=FloatTensorType(shape=[None, 1]))
```

The other variables are the result of scalers and encoders. So I suppose that even If I can use boolean tensor variable, until the C++ backends support mixed type, it won't be practically usable, right?
Can you paste your code here? If you can't share the entire code, just share the part where you build the model pipeline and convert it to onnx.

Sorry for the late reply, was busy with another work item. I seem to be getting a different error with your code. Anyways, we need to add support for boolean type(will add this work item). Do you get this error:https://github.com/onnx/sklearn-onnx/issues/399#issuecomment-583499082, with the code you pasted above?
@prabhat00155 yes I do, I suppose we are limited by onnxruntime there?
Are you running this on `'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/amueller/scipy-2017-sklearn/091d371/notebooks/datasets/titanic3.csv'` dataset as well?

@prabhat00155 yes, you can also refer to https://gist.github.com/victornoel/c4da3089f6792ac1b6fdcdb583886f97: simply uncomment the line at the beginning to use the `female` boolean column instead of the `sex` one.

@prabhat00155 yes, I already know that mapping the bool to float was a possibility.

I was wondering instead of I could be using boolean directly.

Yeah, as I mentioned before, we need to add support for bool in the converters. I'll mark this issue as enhancement and evaluate the work that needs to be done to support bool. In the mean time, you may use the casting approach. Thanks!

For the record, following the fix (#411), I tested again and there is now just one problem with concat:
